title.narrative: Chhattisgarh Public Financial Management and Accountability Program

description.narrative: The objective of the program is to: improve accountability in the management of public finances; strengthen revenue administration; and improve efficiency in delivery of benefits in selected schemes, in the state of Chhattisgarh.

condition.narrative: Advance: The Borrower may withdraw an amount not to exceed two million Dollars ($ 2,000,000) as an advance; provided, however,that if the DLRs in the opinion of the Bank, [is/are] not achieved (or only partially achieved) by the Closing Date, the Borrowershall refund such advance to the Bank promptly upon notice thereof by the Bank. Except as otherwise agreed with the Borrower, theBank shall cancel the amount so refunded. Any further withdrawals requested as an advance under any Category shall be permittedonly on such terms and conditions as the Bank shall specify by notice to the Borrower.

DLI Verification: By no later than 3 (three) months after the Effective Date: (a) hire, and thereafter maintain throughout Programimplementation, an Independent Verification Agency (IVA) to verify the fulfillment of the Disbursement Linked Results in accordancewith terms of reference agreed with the Bank; (b) Undertake, at least annually, in view of the submission of a withdrawalapplication, a verification process, in accordance with the terms of reference agreed with the Bank, to certify the fulfillment ofthe DLRs; and (c) furnish to the Bank corresponding verification report(s), in form and substance agreed with the Bank.

Mid-term Review: The Borrower, together with Chhattisgarh Program implementing Entity shall jointly with the Bank carry out one(1) mid-term review of the Program to assess the status of the Program Implementation, as measured against the indicators andresults framework agreed with the Bank and the legal covenants included/referred to in this Agreement and/or the Program Agreement,and shall incorporate the findings of such review into the Program design for the subsequent years and take all such measuresnecessary for the efficient completion of the Program based on the recommendations of the review and the Bank’s views on thematter.

Program Institutions: The Borrower shall cause Chhattisgarh to maintain, throughout the period of implementation of the Program(a) a Program Steering Committee with a mandate and composition agreed with the Bank; (b) a state Program Management Unit withinthe Directorate of Institutional Finance, with functions, resources agreed with the Bank; and (c) a state Fiscal Cell within theFinance Department, with functions, resources agreed with the Bank.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 3.2: Increase in number of properties in the property register

baseline.value: 572,586 number of properties are presently recorded in the property tax registers related to 10/13 Nagar Nigams after GIS survey

target.value: At least 100,000 number of properties recorded in the property tax registers following GIS survey in selected 47 ULBs

actual.value: Contract to prepare GIS property maps for 47 ULBs has been issued to MapmyIndia. Delays in procurement process means that FY 19-20and FY 20-21 targets likely to be achieved by March 2023.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 2.1: PRIASoft module of Panchayat Enterprise Suite [PES] updated for all receipts and expend by all Village Panchayats

baseline.value: As of 30-Aug-2018, 369/10,966 Village Panchayats with closed month books up to 30-Jun-2018

target.value: 10,000 Village Panchayats with closed month books within 45 days of the last calendar quarter.

actual.value: The e-GramSwaraj portal of MoPR shows that 11,558 Village Panchayats (VP) [out of total of 11,658 VPs] or 99 percent have closedthe accounts up to last month [March 2022].

title.narrative: IR indicator 4.2 Enhancement of Tax Analytics, Information and Audit Systems

baseline.value: Currently VAT system is fully computerized and inhouse MIS & Analytical reports are based on VAT computerized database. GSTanalytics is rudimentary as the MIS is not fully developed and analytics module is yet to be rolled out. No specialized auditmechanisms in place.

target.value: Functional Tax analytics platform available for analysis of GST tax returns, monitoring fraud, return filing status etc. integratedwith existing VAT data. Audit framework and systems created and supported by Analytics platform

actual.value: CTD has migrated to NIC Karnataka’s GST Prime from Pro for tax analytics. One programmer is already based in Bengaluru, but moreare required as indicated above. CTD is yet to recruit data analysts for its BI cell through NICSI for data mining purposes.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 1.3: Structured training of GoCG staff in Public Financial Management and Public Procurement

baseline.value: Existing Accounts Training Schools (ATSs) have inadequate institutional capacity and infrastructure to train GoCG's large pool ofstaff on PFM and Public Procurement. The total number of officers in the above-mentioned cadre are 10 443 including 10% femalestaff.

target.value: At least 3,000 government staff, including 10% female staff trained in Public Financial Management and Public Procurement

actual.value: Online training link on Public Procurement is shared with Director/ Finance for initiating training for Government officials. Dataon trainings completed during FY19-20, FY 20-21 and FY 21-22 is being compiled

title.narrative: PDO Indicator 1: Complete and timely State financial reports available In public domain

baseline.value: Financial reports generated from e-kosh incomplete as expenditures of Public Works and Forest Divisions, Treasury (PAO) and RES arenot reported.

target.value: Complete and timely State financial reports available in public domain.

actual.value: Activities are by and large on track, albeit with some delay As-Is-Study of existing IFMIS’ has been completed and FRS Report forenhanced IFMIS developed. Policy and guidelines on Commitment Control System prepared and issued. Actions on Data integrationinterface between E-Kosh, e-procurement, e-Kuber and e-works (contract management) applications and 100% of payments of all chequedrawing departments through the IFMIS system underway and expected to be completed by August 31, 2022

title.narrative: PDO Indicator 2: Reduction in backlog of audits of local bodies

baseline.value: Huge backlogs exist in audit of PRIs, ULBs and Autonomous Bodies which fall within the purview of audit by the Directorate of LocalFund Audit (LFAD). The total number of units having audit backlog up to FY 17-18 is 11839.

target.value: Audits completed in at least 10,500 units, up to the financial year not earlier than the preceding two financial years.

actual.value: The Directorate of State Audit to take a concerted view to reassess the approach, methodology to be adopted and revise and sharewith the WB team, the target numbers likely to be achieved.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 1.2: Macro-fiscal model developed under a Medium Term Fiscal Framework (MTFF) for forecasting of long-term macro-economic and fiscal indicators

baseline.value: MTFF prepared as part of annual budget exercise, but lacks rigor and clear statement of underlying technical assumptions

target.value: Macro-fiscal model developed under a Medium Term Fiscal Framework (MTFF) for forecasting of long-term macro-economic and fiscalindicators. Forecasts generated through the MTFF used to prepare the statements to meet the requirements of the State FRBM Act, andfor estimating the expenditure ceiling of the budget.

actual.value: Technical work on development of MTFF model has been initiated and expect to be completed by September 2022.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 5.1: Data Sharing and Consent Framework Policy & Guidelines notified

target.value: State notifies Data Sharing and Consent Framework Policy and/or Guidelines

actual.value: Data Exchange Framework guidelines has been prepared by CHiPS, approved by competent authority and published

title.narrative: IR Indicator 5.4: Complaints/ grievances related to selected schemes addressed as per SOP

baseline.value: No formalized digital system to handle grievances raised by beneficiaries

target.value: Fifty percent of grievances lodged for all short-listed schemes closed as per timelines defined in SOP

actual.value: State currently has two grievance related portals. One is developed by CHiPS and other by NIC. Portal developed by CHiPS is forlogging any complaints against any department. NIC portal is only for monitoring purposes. Chief Minister office is using theportal to monitor. IPeG platform will enable a grievance redressal portal which will allow beneficiaries to lodge their complaintsrelated to IPeG only. Not initiated, awaiting development of Data Exchange Platform [i-PEG].

title.narrative: IR Indicator 5.2: Roll-out of Dynamic Beneficiary Registry and Data Exchange Platform

target.value: Hundred Percent of short-listed schemes integrated with Dynamic Beneficiary Registry and Data Exchange Platform

actual.value: IIntegration not yet started, awaiting development of Data Exchange Platform [i-PEG

title.narrative: PDO Indicator 4: Increase in Number of GST registered taxpayers

baseline.value: Number of registered dealers as on 31-03-18 is 1.30 lakhs approx.

target.value: Growth by 25% from baseline in GST registered tax payers

actual.value: As of date, 30% growth has been achieved in number of registered dealers. The total number of GST registrants (excluding TaxDeduction at Source and Tax Collected at Source Dealers as on (April 2022) was 169,193.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 1.1: Development and implementation of new Public Investment Management Framework for capital investment projects

baseline.value: Project Formulation and Implementation Committee headed by Chief Secretary approves all public investment proposals above Rs. 50crores; the process however requires rigor and technical cost benefit analysis.

target.value: Appraisal of at least 10% of all capital investment projects in selected two departments, conducted using the new PIM Framework.

actual.value: Diagnostic Gap Analysis on Public Investment Decision and Management processes has been finalized and approved by competentauthorities. Development and approval of the new PIM Framework to be completed by October 31, 2022

title.narrative: PDO Indicator 3: Increase in property tax collected in selected urban local bodies

baseline.value: Property Tax collected for 44 Nagar Palika for FY17-18 is INR 17.276 crores and INR 8.263 crores for 3 selected Nagar Nigams,including collections against current demand and arrears.

target.value: Increase in property tax collected over the baseline in the selected urban local bodies by 20%

actual.value: Digitization of property tax registers and fresh physical survey of property in several ULBs has resulted in discovery ofadditional tax base; provisional data [to be confirmed] indicates that property tax collections may have increased by 10% or more.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 3.1: Property survey initiated and GIS base map created

baseline.value: Property survey and GIS maps completed for 10 ULBs

target.value: Property survey completed and GIS base map created for 47 selected ULBs

actual.value: Contract to prepare GIS property maps for 47 ULBs has been issued to MapmyIndia. Delays in procurement process means that FY 19-20and FY 20-21 targets likely to be achieved by March 2023.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 2.2: State level dashboard provides enhanced transparency and accountability in ULB performance

baseline.value: TALLY is used for accounting at ULBs; e-Governance initiative underway which envisages design, development and implementation of 12modules, including accrual based double entry accounting module across 168 ULBs across the State

target.value: Finance Budget and Accounting Management module rolled out and fully operational across 13 Nagar Nigams, 44 Nagar Palikas and 112Nagar Panchayats

actual.value: UDD/SUDA confirmed that Finance Budget and Accounting Management Module has been developed with all functionalities and implementedin 3 Nagar Nigams (Bhilai, Birgaon, Jagdalpur). To assist the Bank team to make a more informed assessment of the roll out plansfrom technical and operational perspective, the Bank team proposed a follow-up visit, which will include field visits to at leastone Nagar Nigam, Nagar Palika and Nagar Panchayat and further consultations with UAD/SUDA team. In the WB team’s assessment. thisputs this result at significant risk and may require that GoCG takes a concerted view to assess the approach, methodology adoptedand revise the target numbers likely to be achieved, as may be required.

title.narrative: PDO Indicator 5: Universal use of DBT for validated baseline of beneficiaries in selected schemes

baseline.value: Total number of beneficiaries covered under the five selected schemes are 883,448, of which 0% are DBT compliant

target.value: Use of DBT in 90% of validated baseline of beneficiaries in the shortlisted schemes

actual.value: Activities underway, digitization yet to start.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 4.1: Institutional performance of CTD enhanced, through training of staff and operationalizing of the Help Desk

baseline.value: Non filers of GST return are 28% percentage of active dealers; no proper training schedule/plan; no GST helpdesks

target.value: Decline in GST tax return non-filers to 15% of active dealers; training schedule plan created and GST helpdesks created

actual.value: Institutional capacity is expected to be developed by hiring service tax and tax audit advisors and capacity building training.

title.narrative: IR Indicator 5.3: Number of schemes digitized using Common Application Platform framework

baseline.value: e-Service Delivery Platform (Service Plus) adopted by by GoCG as the Common Application Platform, which will include digitizationof state schemes.

target.value: Fifty state schemes, of which at least 5 schemes focus exclusively on women, digitized.

actual.value: System Integrator has been on-boarded for an end-to-end development of IPeG. One of the modules of IPeG is to enable digitizationof the remaining 45 schemes.
